Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Robust, Low-power Strategies for Unattended Micrometeorological Buoy Deployments in Extreme Cold and Freezing Spray
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is for the testing/development of low-power methods to mitigate the effects of ice and liquid water on the performance and data quality of air-sea momentum and heat flux sensors. It utilizes cold chambers and wind tunnel facilities to develop and test active deicing strategies that have been successfully used in aircraft applications. The techniques will be adapted and optimized for the low-power scenario of an overwinter buoy on Lake Ontario. If successful, this approach could enable direct measurements of momentum, heat and moisture from the lake into the atmosphere during the winter. Such measurements are needed for better modeling and prediction of lake effect snow, which frequently impact communities downwind of the North American Great Lakes, causing loss of life, destruction of property and infrastructure, and commercial and social disruption. Robust, low-power strategies to mitigate ice accumulation on sensors and structures would also have broader applications beyond this research application. This project will partially fund graduate students at SUNY Albany and Penn State who will play an integral role in the testing, and thereby receive valuable training and experience that is part of their graduate education.

The overarching scientific goal motivating this project is to improve parameterizations of lake-atmosphere momentum, heat, and moisture fluxes that will lead to better lake effect snow forecasts. Direct measurements of fluxes using the eddy covariance (EC) technique during the winter would be most useful to develop/improve surface flux parameterizations, test research hypotheses, and examine model performance under extreme forcing. To date, difficulties associated with measuring turbulence and fluxes from power-limited platforms during hard winter conditions have precluded collection of such data. As a step toward developing the capability for EC flux measurements in these conditions, this project will adopt a technique from the aviation industry and explore the feasibility of using short, intense pulses of mechanical vibrations and/or heat to dislodge ice or water from the instrument surfaces. These methods will be tested under simulated freezing spray conditions. This de-icing method is expected to be much more power efficient than simply heating the sensors to keep them ice free. If successful, the method is intended to be deployed on buoys with extra buoyancy and high righting moment to resist ice buildup on other parts of the superstructure. The buoys would provide winter time measurements from the ice-free parts of the Great Lakes. Successful demonstration of these techniques will be published in the peer reviewed literature, enabling application by other researchers focused on micrometeorology in extreme environments, and, more broadly, applications where ice mitigation is critical and available power is limited.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective is to advance the capability for buoy-based atmospheric turbulence and water-atmosphere flux measurements in extreme wintertime marine environments. We are addressing two major challenges that affect performance of 3D ultrasonic (sonic) anemometers and infrared gas analyzers: icing and liquid water. Because power availability on buoys is often limited, we are investigating low-power solutions to overcome the detrimental effects of icing and liquid water on sensor performance.  

 

Intellectual Merit

To address icing, we worked collaboratively with a small business in Ithaca New York (Innovative Dynamics, Inc). The low-power de-icing approach involves applying heat at the instrument/ice interface to weaken the ice bond, and then applying mechanical vibration to help shed the ice from the instrument. We conducted laboratory tests in the Penn State Wind Tunnel Icing Facility to understand patterns of ice accumulation on the instrument and how the sonic anemometer responded to the onset of icing conditions. We also made preliminary tests of low-power de-icing strategies using heaters and de-icing vibration actuators. We built a prototype de-icing system that was deployed during winter at the Whiteface Mountain Summit Observatory in New York State Adirondack Park. We found that we could de-ice and maintain measurement under most (but not all) conditions using an average of 6 Watts of power. We built an icing chamber in our laboratory to test various low-power heater and impact actuator configurations, including a custom composite sleeve designed and built by a small company in Schenectady NY (Vistex Composites, Inc). 

 

To address liquid water, we developed a prototype low-power liquid water rejection system (the ?sneeze?). The sneeze was combined with the Campbell Scientific ?vortex inlet? which uses a bypass flow to generate a centrifugal force to reject larger particles and water droplets from the sample stream. The sneeze was integrated onto a 2-m discus buoy and deployed in the Gulf of Maine for 2 weeks in October 2020. The sneeze was successful in keeping liquid water out of the gas analyzers in winds to 12 ms-1 with breaking waves and spray that tripped the sneeze sensors dozens of times over a several hour period. 

 

Broader Impacts

The low-power techniques have potential to make atmospheric turbulence and flux measurements in extreme environments more feasible. The ability to collect these types of data in such conditions will facilitate development and evaluation of improved physical models of surface-atmosphere exchange that do not rely on extrapolation of parameterizations developed for moderate conditions. We are focused on atmospheric turbulence sensors; however, the techniques for low-power de-icing could be applied to other types of meteorological sensors, or even unrelated applications. 

 

This project was a collaboration with two small businesses un Upstate New York and a leading instrumentation manufacturer. The low-power sneeze design was presented as part of an AMS conference poster. This project supported a graduate student who earned his M.S. degree and has developed into a talented research technician with a broad range of field and lab skills whos services are in demand at our university. 

 

This project was highly productive in terms of the range of laboratory and field activities that were done, the development of the icing chamber in our laboratory for de-icing testing, and the field testing of the low-power sneeze system. Nonetheless, COVID 19 dealt a major blow to our lab icing chamber testing that was geared toward 1) determining how far the power consumption of the de-icing system could be further reduced/minimized compared with the 6W that were required during the Whiteface Mountain deployment; and 2) obtaining repeatable de-icing success. As COVID 19 was ramping up in March 2020, we were in the midst of performing tests in the icing chamber with different geometric configurations and actuator power profiles. We lost access to the lab between March-June, and upon returning to the lab we were not able to resume testing due to other project demands including the Gulf of Maine buoy deployment. Similarly, our data analysis and manuscript preparation schedule slipped. We intend to submit a manuscript in late 2020/early 2021 that describes our techniques and test results.
